Spatial 20:
Spatial 21:
Spatial 22:
Spatial 23:
Spatial 24:
Date: 1886-05-04
Description: Postal card offering $100 reward for apprehension of John B. Gray, "who left Trenton April 29." The card provides a detailed physical description of Gray, noting "a peculiar shaped leg, with prominent muscles on fore part of leg above knee." Card is addressed to the Chief of Police, Selma, Alabama.

Date: 1861.0
Description: Recruitment poster for Company K of the Cameron Light Guards (88th Pennsylvania Infantry Regiment) commanded by Colonel George P. M'Lean and mustered in in and around Philadelphia. William F. Powell served as captain of Company K.

Date: 1840-09-25
Description: Circular on Whig party victories in recent Maine state elections. Announces victory of Edward Kent as governor, as well as four unnamed Whig members of Congress and sixteen state senators. Promises future victories in national elections. Signed by members of Whig State Committee: S.R. Lyman, Nathan Cummings, William C. Hammatt, J. Wingate Carr. Augusta, Sept. 25, 1840.

Spatial 5:
Spatial 6:
Spatial 7:
Spatial 8:
Spatial 9:
Spatial 10:
Spatial 11:
Spatial 12:
Spatial 13:

Spatial 16:
Spatial 17:
Spatial 18:
Spatial 19:
Spatial 20:
Spatial 21:
Spatial 22:
Spatial 23:
Spatial 24:
Date: 1894.0
Description: Letter or card from Andrew D. Cowles appealing to members of the "Republican Party of Iredell County" to not align themselves with the Populists in this election, but to vote for "Furches and Faircloth and other Republican judges and solicitors, Sharpe and Brown for the Senate, and Morrow for the House." He concludes with: "Remember, Republicans, poor bleeding Kansas! Take the advice of the National Republican Committee; hold to your true principles; defend your colors; vote the Republican ticket and be saved."
Subject-Topic: Elections; Political campaigns; Politics and government; United States--History--Civil War, 1861-1865; Commerce;
Type-DCMI: Text

Date: 1935-04-17T00:00:00Z
Description: Pamphlet by Charles L. Van Noppen, "a Jeffersonian Democrat," condemning the small loan bill being discussed in the senate. "Designing interests have frozen money. Usury in its most vicious forms is everywhere, and a cowed people seem either too ignorant or too cowardly to protest. Thus the Depression continues and prosperity waits in vain. Mr Legislator, redeem your state!"

Date: 1869-10-25
Description: One page proclamation by Governor Harrison Reed announcing a day of thanksgiving for November 18, 1869, to give thanks for "peace, social order, and good government." Florida citizens were to abstain from work and attend church in honor of the day. Includes image of an eagle and American flag.

Spatial 5:

Spatial 7:
Spatial 8:
Spatial 9:
Spatial 10:
Spatial 11:
Spatial 12:
Spatial 13:
Spatial 14:
Spatial 15:
Spatial 16:
Spatial 17:
Spatial 18:
Spatial 19:
Spatial 20:
Spatial 21:
Spatial 22:
Spatial 23:
Spatial 24:
Date: 1801; 1802; 1803; 1804; 1805; 1806; 1807; 1808; 1809; 1810; 1811; 1812; 1813; 1814; 1815; 1816; 1817; 1818; 1819; 1820; 1821; 1822; 1823; 1824; 1825; 1826; 1827; 1828; 1829; 1830; 1831; 1832; 1833; 1834; 1835; 1836; 1837; 1838; 1839; 1840; 1841; 1842; 1843; 1844; 1845; 1846; 1847; 1848; 1849; 1850; 1851; 1852; 1853; 1854; 1855; 1856; 1857; 1858; 1859; 1860; 1861; 1862; 1863; 1864; 1865; 1866; 1867; 1868; 1869; 1870; 1871; 1872; 1873; 1874; 1875; 1876; 1877; 1878; 1879; 1880; 1881; 1882; 1883; 1884; 1885; 1886; 1887; 1888; 1889; 1890; 1891; 1892; 1893; 1894; 1895; 1896; 1897; 1898; 1899; 1900
Description: This document was written/produced by E. C. Allen of Augusta, Maine and he describes various products which could be sold for profit by "any man, woman or boy," (as agents) including "National Washing Compound" and "A Pure Vegetable Salve" which costs 25 cents a box but only costs about 3 cents a box to make. Allen states he can furnish readers with the "Horse Tamer's Secrets" for a price, which buyers can in turn sell to others. He does offer refunds. Page two includes a list articles that can be sold and the cost to agents per gross as well as more salesmanship from Allen. Also included are letters written by individuals to Allen which say things like "Your recipes came to hand all right and they are just the things I wanted."
Subject-Topic: Advertising; Commerce
Type-DCMI: Text
Type-AAT: broadsides; circular letters; advertisements

Spatial 22:
Spatial 23:
Spatial 24:
Date: 1903.0
Description: One-sided circular letter which provides specific reasons as to why Newton C. Blanchard "should not be elected governor of Louisiana." The writer, possibly H. Dickson Bruns, is a supporter of Blanchard's rival, General Jastremski, who, according to the author, appeals to the people, whereas Blanchard appeals to officials and grafters. The letter is dated circa 1903.

Spatial 18:
Spatial 19:
Spatial 20:
Spatial 21:
Spatial 22:
Spatial 23:
Spatial 24:
Date: 1880.0
Description: 4-page advertisement from 1880, soliciting agents to sell "The illustrated household magazine", published monthly by George Stinson & Co., general publishers and printers, Portland, Maine. Subscribers will also receive for free "six elegant chromos" and "thirty art plate pictures". Each number also contains two pieces of new music.

Date: 1909; 1910
Description: Advance notice for volume 1 of "A history of New Hanover County and the lower Cape Fear Region" by Alfred Moore Waddell, to be published in January and available for $2.50. The book will include "a map showing the site and name of each of the original plantations", with biographical information about the plantation owners as well as other early settlers.

Spatial 24:
Date: 1900.0
Description: Advertisement for The American Tribune Colonization Company of Indianapolis, Ind., circa 1900, encouraging "home seekers" to join the 100,000 acre colony established in Georgia, 60 miles south of Macon, in the "fruit belt." The advertisement explains the organization of the communal colony and the potential bounty of the land.

Title: A letter to the democracy
Country: United States
State: Maryland
County: Baltimore (Md.);
City:
Spatial 5:
Spatial 6:
Spatial 7:
Spatial 8:
Spatial 9:
Spatial 10:
Spatial 11:
Spatial 12:
Spatial 13:
Spatial 14:
Spatial 15:
Spatial 16:
Spatial 17:
Spatial 18:
Spatial 19:
Spatial 20:
Spatial 21:
Spatial 22:
Spatial 23:
Spatial 24:
Date: 1861-08-10
Description: Open letter, signed at end by "M.H.W.," decrying arrest of pro-Confederate Baltimore officials after martial law declared May 13, 1861, including mayor George William Brown, city council, and police commissioner. Compares arrests to case of Edward Deering, arrested during reign of Queen Elizabeth I. "If you have any desire to perpetuate the blessings of civil and religious liberty you will at once demand that this wicked fratricidal war shall cease. It would be far better to acknowledge the independence of the Confederate States, than to incur the guilt of murder."
Subject-Topic: United States--History--Civil War, 1861-1865;
Type-DCMI: Text
Type-AAT: circular letters;
Identifier-DukeID: bdsmd40981
Source: Broadsides and Ephemera Collection
Folder: MD4
Extent: 3 scans
Digital Collection: Broadsides and Ephemera Collection

Title: A proclamation by the governor of North Carolina
Country: United States
State: North Carolina
County: Alamance County (N.C.);
City:
Spatial 5:
Spatial 6:
Spatial 7:
Spatial 8:
Spatial 9:
Spatial 10:
Spatial 11:
Spatial 12:
Spatial 13:
Spatial 14:
Spatial 15:
Spatial 16:
Spatial 17:
Spatial 18:
Spatial 19:
Spatial 20:
Spatial 21:
Spatial 22:
Spatial 23:
Spatial 24:
Date: 1870-03-07
Description: Proclamation by governor William Holden that Alamance County, North Carolina, is "in a state of insurrection." Describes assaults and hangings by armed bands, including of a schoolteacher; forced flight of county postmaster, and various crimes and general lawlessness. "Every citizen, of whatever party or color, must be absolutely free to express his political opinions, and must be safe in his own house. These outrages and these violations of law must and SHALL cease." Events known as Kirk-Holden War.
Subject-Topic: Crime; Reconstruction (U.S. history, 1865-1877); Race relations;
Type-DCMI: Text
Type-AAT: broadsides; ephemera;
Identifier-DukeID: bdsnc031696

Date: 1921; 1922; 1923; 1924; 1925; 1926; 1927; 1928; 1929; 1930

Spatial 20:
Spatial 21:
Spatial 22:
Spatial 23:
Spatial 24:
Date: 1932.0
Description: Pamphlet calling for supporters of Bishop James Cannon, Jr. to contribute money to a fund for Cannon's trial. "A generous response will not only afford relief from the crushing burden of financial obligations, but will also show an appreciation of Bishop Cannon's unselfish services and great sacrifices -- sacrifices which have made him a real martyr to the cause of Prohibition and Protestant Christianity." Cannon, a champion of Prohibition, is being charged with breaking laws concerning contributions to his campaign against anti-Prohibition candidates.
Subject-Topic: Religion; Politics and government;
Type-DCMI: Text
Type-AAT: pamphlets;

Description: Four-page statement and appeal from the friends of Bishop James Cannon, Jr., a leader of the Prohibition movement, requesting aid and support for his legal troubles, and describing how his work for the Commission on Temperance and Social Service has brought him political enemies who have kept him "under indictment since October, 1931".

Description: Broadside issued by the Executive Committee of the Anti-Saloon League urging the citizens of Wadesboro to vote against having saloons and distilleries in town. "Is Wadesboro, that has so much to be proud of, to be the dumping ground of all the evils of the whiskey traffic in the future?"

Spatial 23:
Spatial 24:
Date: 1902; 1903
Description: Four-page advertisement for a series of lectures given by A. R. Crook, Professor of Mineralogy and Economic Geology at Northwestern University. Lectures include: "From Moscow to Siberia," "Relation of Geology to Man," "Yellowstone National Park," "The Grand Canyon," "St. Petersburg and the Caucasus," and "The Mexico of Today." Last page includes press comments and other endorsements.

Spatial 22:
Spatial 23:
Spatial 24:
Date: 1883.0
Description: Four page leaflet describing accident insurance. "The members are all placed together and a distinction made only in the amount paid each according to the Grade of membership. The difference in the amounts corresponding to proportion of risk according to the varied professions. All pay a like amount on claims arising."
Subject-Topic: Commerce
Type-DCMI: Text
Type-AAT: advertisements; leaflets
Identifier-DukeID: bdsmd61044

Spatial 18:

Spatial 22:
Spatial 23:
Spatial 24:
Date: 1866-02-19
Description: Open letter from George B. Loring, U.S. congressman from Massachusetts, to editor of the Boston Journal. Concerning Swampscott riot, in which George W. Stone, publicly rejoicing over assassination of Abraham Lincoln, was tarred and feathered by a crowd. Loring condemns recent decision by state to prosecute Stone's attackers criminally. Dated Feb. 19, 1866.
Subject-Topic: Crime

Country: United States
State: North Carolina
County: Craven County (N.C.)
City: New Bern (N.C.)
Spatial 5:
Spatial 6:
Spatial 7:
Spatial 8:
Spatial 9:
Spatial 10:
Spatial 11:
Spatial 12:
Spatial 13:
Spatial 14:
Spatial 15:
Spatial 16:
Spatial 17:
Spatial 18:
Spatial 19:
Spatial 20:
Spatial 21:
Spatial 22:
Spatial 23:
Spatial 24:
Date: 1870; 1871; 1872; 1873; 1874; 1875; 1876; 1877; 1878; 1879; 1880
Description: Three page newspaper section with an ad for O'Connor's Saloon, "oysters fresh and fat at all hours," on the first page. The next two pages contain an "Address to the Colored Voters of Craven County" by the "Central Seymour and Blair Club of Craven County at Newbern." The address urges African Americans to "come forth from the union Leagues which now hold you bound both body and soul" and vote against the Radical ticket in the upcoming elections.
Subject-Topic: Advertising; African Americans--History; Elections; Fraternal organizations; Manners and customs; Political campaigns; Politics and government; Race relations; Reconstruction (U.S. history, 1865-1877); Speeches, addresses, etc.;

Spatial 23:

Date: 1873.0
Description: Three-page, double-sided resignation letter addressed to the members of the Mount Vernon Ladies Association by the outgoing regent, Miss A.P. Cunningham, who details her long-standing efforts towards the preservation of George Washington's home as well as the nervous strain and health issues that forced her resignation.

Title: Advertisement for Bovine Salve
Country: United States
State: Maine
County: Kennebec County (Me.)
City: Augusta (Me.)
Spatial 5:
Spatial 6:
Spatial 7:
Spatial 8:
Spatial 9:
Spatial 10:
Spatial 11:
Spatial 12:
Spatial 13:
Spatial 14:
Spatial 15:
Spatial 16:
Spatial 17:
Spatial 18:
Spatial 19:
Spatial 20:
Spatial 21:
Spatial 22:
Spatial 23:
Spatial 24:
Date: 1890; 1891; 1892; 1893; 1894; 1895; 1896; 1897; 1898; 1899; 1900; 1901; 1902; 1903; 1904; 1905; 1906; 1907; 1908; 1909; 1910; 1911; 1912; 1913; 1914; 1915; 1916; 1917; 1918; 1919; 1920
Description: 4-page advertisement for Bovine Salve, "the monarch of emollients" and the "greatest subduer of inflammatory diseases on earth!!" Bovine Salve was manufactured by The Bovine Medicine Company of Augusta, Maine. Ingredients are "purely vegetable, containing neither Mercury, Bismuth, Arsenic, or other derivatives". Usage benefits eczema, and corrects "all tendency of eruptions and causes the skin to assume a whiteness and softness of texture that are positive indications of natural and healthy skin."
Subject-Topic: Agriculture; Advertising; Health and hygiene; Commerce; Race relations; Manners and customs

Spatial 22:
Spatial 23:
Spatial 24:
Date: 1842-03-01
Description: Advertisement by A. McKenzie for a stud opportunity with "the fine race horse John Marshall, Will stand the present season at my stable in Tippah county, Miss.," and is offered for breeding with mares for "$10 cash the single leap; $20 the season," and "$30 to insure a mare in foal, payable when the fact is ascertained." John Marshall's pedigree and racing performance history is also included.
Subject-Topic: Advertising
Type-DCMI: Text
Type-AAT: broadsides; advertisements

Spatial 22:
Spatial 23:
Spatial 24:
Date: 1945-09
Description: 5-page advertisement for the Crocker-McElwain paper company, published in the Paper News Poster. Displays ten patriotic wartime posters: "I'm glad to be an American"; "Praise the Lord and pass the ammunition"; "The Navy's name for gossip is scuttle-butt"; Dumbarton Oaks: Unite now to prevent World-War III"; "Damn the torpedoes, full speed ahead"; "Liberty strikes to preserve the four freedoms"; "The pen and the sword"; "Printing in war and peace"; "By the Eternal! No war is ever ended until somebody is knocked out"

Date: 1870; 1871; 1872; 1873; 1874; 1875; 1876; 1877; 1878; 1879; 1880
Description: Order form and letter of agency for Sun-Light Oil, manufactured by M. Wagner & Co. of Marshall, Michigan. A trial bottle will be sent along with a "Family Right" for the product for $2, provided the undersigned will "agree not to divulge or make known any ingredients composing the Oil, or to manufacture the same for any purpose whatever, except for use in my own family."

Title: Ambassador Bryce to deliver address
Country: United States
State: Great Britain
County: North Carolina
City: Wake County (N.C.)
Spatial 5: Orange County (N.C.)
Spatial 6: New Hanover County (N.C.)
Spatial 7: Guilford County (N.C.)
Spatial 8: Raleigh (N.C.)
Spatial 9: Hillsborough (N.C.)
Spatial 10: Wilmington (N.C.)
Spatial 11: Greensboro (N.C.)
Spatial 12:
Spatial 13:
Spatial 14:
Spatial 15:
Spatial 16:
Spatial 17:
Spatial 18:
Spatial 19:
Spatial 20:
Spatial 21:
Spatial 22:
Spatial 23:
Spatial 24:
Date: 1909-11-04T00:00:00Z
Description: Announcement in the Raleigh News and Observer that James Bryce, British Ambassador to the United States, and author of "The American Commonwealth", will address the annual meeting of the North Carolina Literary and Historical Association in Raleigh, on November 4, 1909. The meeting will include "the presentation...of the bust of William A. Graham...by the sculptor Ruckstuhl..." Other meeting participants mentioned are: Capt. Thos. W. Mason and Mr. Frank Nash, of Hillsboro; Hon. Junius Davis, of Wilmington; Mr. Clarence H. Poe; Col. J. Bryan Grimes; Mr. A. M. Scales, of Greensboro; Chairman R. H. Battle, Dr. D. H. Hill, Mr. R. D. W. Connor. "The announcement of the award of the Patterson Memorial Cup for the most notable literary production of the year will also be made at this meeting." Railroad travel to the meeting should be economical as the "National Farmers' Congress" is also meeting in Raleigh the same week.
Subject-Topic: Speeches, addresses, etc.; Literature; Politics and government; Manners and customs; Travel; Transportation; Agriculture;
Type-DCMI: Text
Type-AAT: newspaper clippings; broadsides;
Identifier-DukeID: bdsnc071931

Folder: NC7
Extent: 1 scan

Title: American Progress Bulletin No. 1
Country: United States
State: Louisiana
County: Orleans Parish (La.)
City: New Orleans (La.)
Spatial 5:
Spatial 6:
Spatial 7:
Spatial 8:
Spatial 9:
Spatial 10:
Spatial 11:
Spatial 12:
Spatial 13:
Spatial 14:
Spatial 15:
Spatial 16:
Spatial 17:
Spatial 18:
Spatial 19:
Spatial 20:
Spatial 21:
Spatial 22:
Spatial 23:
Spatial 24:
Date: 1930; 1931; 1932; 1933; 1934; 1935
Description: One-page circular letter printed by newspaper the AMERICAN PROGRESS, circa 1935. Headline reads "J.P. Morgan & Company Points Way for Capone's Release." It's addressed to gangster Al Capone. It strongly criticizes the relationship between J.P. Morgan (and his associates) and the federal government and what he's been allowed to get away with, unlike Al Capone who is in prison for tax evasion. It goes as far as to claim that Morgan's company does the same thing but with federal approval. The catalyst for the letter is the recent assault of Huey P. Long on Long Island. This publication was supported by Huey P. Long.
Subject-Topic: Politics and government
Type-DCMI: Text
Type-AAT: newspaper clippings; circular letters

Date: 1857-06-24
Description: One-paged broadside by Frederick Schley accusing Bradley T. Johnson of being a would-be assassin. Schley writes that Johnson charged him with a cane in the drugstore of Robert Johnson, and that they began to fight but were then separated. Schley concludes by calling Bradley Johnson a coward.

Description: Leaflet by Silas Lucas Rose of Goldsboro to O. Max Gardner, Democratic governor of North Carolina stating that "our house (North Carolina) needs cleaning. You are our superintendent, are you going to have it cleaned? You and your crowd, I mean my old crowd, messed it up."
Subject-Topic: Politics and government;
Type-DCMI: Text
Type-AAT: leaflets;
Identifier-DukeID: bdsnc102153

Spatial 18:

Spatial 21:
Spatial 22:
Spatial 23:
Spatial 24:
Date: 19074-03-30
Description: Open letter from H.W. McNatt, MD, to the residents of Robeson County, concerning high incidence of typhoid fever, tuberculosis, consumption, and other illnesses, and blaming them on polluted drinking water and "living in dirty infected houses." Encourages cleaner surroundings and better sanitation.

Spatial 22:
Spatial 23:
Spatial 24:
Date: 1905-11-18T00:00:00Z
Description: Four-page letter from D. G. Purse to Col. J. H. Estill "with reference to a difference between them at the annual reunion of the Georgia Division of Confederate Veterans at Macon, Ga., Nov. 8th-9th, 1905." Purse accuses Estill of using "heated and intemperate language" at the reunion and criticizes his military service record.

Title: Andersonville. The relations of the "Confederate government" to federal prisoners
Country: United States
State: Georgia
County: Louisiana
City: Sumter County (Ga.)
Spatial 5: Andersonville (Ga.)
Spatial 6:
Spatial 7:
Spatial 8:
Spatial 9:

Spatial 11:

Spatial 13:
Spatial 14:

Spatial 16:
Spatial 17:
Spatial 18:
Spatial 19:
Spatial 20:
Spatial 21:
Spatial 22:
Spatial 23:
Spatial 24:
Date: 1876-01-17
Description: Open letter from Dr. Joseph Jones of New Orleans to Benjamin H. Hill, congressman from Georgia. Describes poor conditions at Andersonville (Ga.) Prison, used by Confederacy to house Union prisoners during Civil War. Special attention given to poor sanitary and health conditions at the Confederate Prison. Dated Jan. 17, 1876. Includes brief letter by Robert E. Lee on subject of Civil War prisons. Housed with Louisiana broadsides.

Title: Announcement of Gen. Julian S. Carr for United States Senator
Country: United States
State: North Carolina
County: Durham County (N.C.)
City: Durham (N.C.)
Spatial 5:
Spatial 6:
Spatial 7:
Spatial 8:
Spatial 9:
Spatial 10:
Spatial 11:
Spatial 12:
Spatial 13:
Spatial 14:
Spatial 15:
Spatial 16:
Spatial 17:
Spatial 18:
Spatial 19:
Spatial 20:
Spatial 21:
Spatial 22:
Spatial 23:
Spatial 24:
Date: 1900; 1901
Description: Announcement by Gen. Julian S. Carr, with portrait, declaring his candidacy for United States Senator for the term beginning March 4, 1901, and asking for support from "the democratic electors of North Carolina" in the primary election on November 16, 1900. He promises to "strive to protect our people from...Force Bills and...preserve from Federal interference our new Constitutional Amendment." He refers to "the old Confederate veteran" who realizes that a new generation will soon be in charge, but those who fought in the Civil War "will feel a brighter satisfaction to be again represented in our highest Council by one of the "boys that wore the Gray."
Subject-Topic: Political campaigns; Elections; Politics and government; United States--History--Civil War, 1861-1865; Reconstruction (U.S. history, 1865-1877); Race relations; Agriculture; Commerce; Education; Manners and customs; Military campaigns;
Type-DCMI: Text; Still Image;
Type-AAT: broadsides; newspaper clippings; circular letters;
Identifier-DukeID: bdsnc071879
Source: Broadsides and Ephemera Collection
Folder: NC7
Extent: 1 scan
Digital Collection: Broadsides and Ephemera Collection

State: Louisiana
County:
City:

Spatial 9:

Spatial 11:
Spatial 12:
Spatial 13:
Spatial 14:
Spatial 15:
Spatial 16:
Spatial 17:
Spatial 18:
Spatial 19:
Spatial 20:
Spatial 21:
Spatial 22:
Spatial 23:
Spatial 24:
Date: 1891-10-22
Description: Single-sided broadside announcing upcoming lecture and exhibition of oil paintings at East End Baptist Church, city unknown. "An evening of great enjoyment. From the city of destruction to the celestial gate, John Bunyan's wonderful and immortal dream, 'Pilgrim's Progress,' presented in panorama. Twenty original oil paintings ... by Rev. Adam Chambers ... with descriptive and explanatory lecture...." Snippet of verse entitled "Uncle Ned" handwritten on back, author unknown; apparently based on "Old Uncle Ned" by Stephen Foster.
Subject-Topic: Entertainment; Manners and customs; Art
Type-DCMI: Text
Type-AAT: broadsides
Identifier-DukeID: bdsla40661

Folder: LA4

Title: Announcement of Populist political gathering, Aug. 31, 1894
Country: United States
State: Arkansas
County: Washington County (Ark.)
City: Fayetteville (Ark.)
Spatial 5:
Spatial 6:
Spatial 7:
Spatial 8:
Spatial 9:
Spatial 10:
Spatial 11:
Spatial 12:
Spatial 13:
Spatial 14:
Spatial 15:
Spatial 16:
Spatial 17:
Spatial 18:
Spatial 19:
Spatial 20:
Spatial 21:
Spatial 22:
Spatial 23:
Spatial 24:
Date: 1894-08-31
Description: Circular letter inviting men over age 17 to attend Populist political gathering, to be held Aug. 31, 1894 in Fayetteville, Arkansas. "We have the ground secured for camp near the Red Mill. We hope to make this the largest political gathering ever had in this county, and it will be if Populists do their duty." Handwritten at top: West Fork Township. Letter notes that township is expected to furnish 50 men (number written in by hand). Signed "E.M. Macy, Chm'n Co. Cen. COmmittee."
Subject-Topic: Politics and government
Type-DCMI: Text
Type-AAT: circular letters
Identifier-DukeID: bdsar10046

Folder: AR1
Extent: 1 scan

Spatial 22:
Spatial 23:
Spatial 24:
Date: 1906-06-11T00:00:00Z
Description: James A. B. Scherer, President of the faculty, submitted his annual report to the Board of Trustees of Newberry College. Enrollment was the highest in the school's history. Measles was the most challenging ailment. The Department of Technology opened successfully at the beginning of the term. Donations were made.
Subject-Topic: Education; Manners and customs;

Spatial 24:
Date: 1908-08-12T00:00:00Z
Description: Circular letter announcing the annual reunion of the Eleventh Regiment Minnesota Volunteer Infantry Association, to be held on September 2, 1908, at the Minneapolis court house. A "grand State Reunion of Minnesota Civil War Volunteers will be held at the State Fair grounds" later that afternoon. The reverse side of the letter contains an "In Memoriam" list of members deceased since 1906.

Title: Answers regarding women's suffrage
Country: United States
State: Massachusetts
County: Middlesex County (Mass.)
City: Boston (Mass.)
Spatial 5:
Spatial 6:
Spatial 7:
Spatial 8:
Spatial 9:
Spatial 10:
Spatial 11:
Spatial 12:
Spatial 13:
Spatial 14:
Spatial 15:
Spatial 16:
Spatial 17:
Spatial 18:
Spatial 19:
Spatial 20:
Spatial 21:
Spatial 22:
Spatial 23:
Spatial 24:
Date: 1883-02-20
Description: This circular letter, dated Feb. 20, 1883 includes a list of "plain questions" possibly submitted by women to the legislators who "represent (?)" them and the answers received. The questions appear to have originated on an anonymous circular, thus the reason for the answers to be presented in the same manner. Also on the circular letter is an editorial written to the Editor of the Herald by Lucy Stone on suffrage and mormonism, focusing largely on the practice of polygamy.
Subject-Topic: Women; Politics and government
Type-DCMI: Text
Type-AAT: circular letters

Date: 1838.0
Description: One-page advertisement by the Massachusetts Anti-Slavery Society for participants in a fair to raise funds for the salary of the society's general agent, Rev. John A. Collins. Extra money supports the society's work. The fair will be held in Boston in October.

Source: Broadsides and Ephemera Collection
Folder: MA1

Digital Collection: Broadsides and Ephemera Collection
Title: Anti-Tobacco "Pipe and Poverty"
Country: United States
State: Maine
County: Kennebec County (Me.)
City: Winthrop (Me.)
Spatial 5:
Spatial 6:
Spatial 7:
Spatial 8:
Spatial 9:
Spatial 10:
Spatial 11:
Spatial 12:
Spatial 13:
Spatial 14:
Spatial 15:
Spatial 16:
Spatial 17:
Spatial 18:
Spatial 19:
Spatial 20:
Spatial 21:
Spatial 22:
Spatial 23:
Spatial 24:
Date: 1890.0
Description: Two-sided circular letter titled "Pipe and Poverty" is an anti-tobacco tract in which the author connects the act of smoking with poverty. He states that smokers spend so much money on cigars, chewed tobacco, and pipes that they cannot afford to take care of their families. He further states that tobacco is the "cause of much physical and intellectual evil." He largely seeks an audience of young men "starting in life (as the author did) with little or not means, and dependent on their industry, economy and the blessing of God."
Subject-Topic: Manners and customs
Type-DCMI: Text
Type-AAT: circular letters
Identifier-DukeID: bdsme11078
Source: Broadsides and Ephemera Collection
Folder: ME1
Extent: 2 scans
Digital Collection: Broadsides and Ephemera Collection
Title: Anti-Walmsley circular letter
Country: United States
State: Louisiana
County: Orleans Parish (La.)
City: New Orleans (La.)
Spatial 5:
Spatial 6:
Spatial 7:
Spatial 8:
Spatial 9:
Spatial 10:
Spatial 11:
Spatial 12:
Spatial 13:
Spatial 14:
Spatial 15:
Spatial 16:
Spatial 17:
Spatial 18:
Spatial 19:
Spatial 20:
Spatial 21:
Spatial 22:
Spatial 23:
Spatial 24:
Date: 1935.0
Description: Two-sided circular letter created by Huey P. Long in circa 1935. Side one has the headline "Walmsley will have to give New Orleans a chance to get from under his squander" and proceeds to criticize Walmsley. Side two has the headline "Here are the facts concerning the issuing of bonds for US government money" and discusses Long's issues with state bonds and government money and how they've affected citizen of Louisiana in the past.
Subject-Topic: Politics and government
Type-DCMI: Text
Type-AAT: circular letters
Identifier-DukeID: bdsla60742

Folder: LA6

Title: Appeal to the people of Tennessee
Country: United States
State: Tennessee
County: Davidson County (Tenn.)
City: Nashville (Tenn.)
Spatial 5:
Spatial 6:
Spatial 7:
Spatial 8:
Spatial 9:
Spatial 10:
Spatial 11:
Spatial 12:
Spatial 13:
Spatial 14:
Spatial 15:
Spatial 16:
Spatial 17:
Spatial 18:
Spatial 19:
Spatial 20:
Spatial 21:
Spatial 22:
Spatial 23:
Spatial 24:
Date: 1862-03-18
Description: Single-page broadside of an appeal issued by Andrew Johnson, upon his appointment by President Lincoln as military governor of Tennessee: "I have been appointed, in the absence of the regular and established State authorities, as Military Governor for the time being, to preserve the public property of the State, to give the protection of law actively enforced to her citizens, and as speedily as may be, to restore her government to the same condition as before the existing rebellion....And for this purpose, I respectfully, but earnestly invite all the people of Tennessee, desirous or willing to see a restoration of her ancient government, without distinction of party-affiliations or past political opinions or action to unite with me, by counsel and co-operative agency, to accomplish this great end."
Subject-Topic: United States--History--Civil War, 1861-1865; Politics and government; Military campaigns; Speeches, addresses, etc.;
Type-DCMI: Text
Type-AAT: broadsides;
Identifier-DukeID: bdstn022962

Title: Are the people of North Carolina going to elect Judge Francis D. Winston Lieutenant-Governor?
Country: United States
State: North Carolina
County: Edgecombe County (N.C.)
City: Nash County (N.C.)
Spatial 5: Bertie County (N.C.)
Spatial 6: Rocky Mount (N.C.)
Spatial 7: Windsor (N.C.)
Spatial 8:
Spatial 9:
Spatial 10:
Spatial 11:
Spatial 12:
Spatial 13:
Spatial 14:
Spatial 15:
Spatial 16:
Spatial 17:
Spatial 18:
Spatial 19:
Spatial 20:
Spatial 21:
Spatial 22:
Spatial 23:
Spatial 24:
Date: 1890; 1891; 1892; 1893; 1894; 1895; 1896; 1897; 1898; 1899; 1900; 1901; 1902; 1903; 1904
Description: 1904 political cartoon by F. A. Hull depicting Judge Francis D. Winston, who is white, riding in a horse-drawn carriage with Hon. George H. White, who is Black, and stereotypically portrayed as a flashy-dressing, cigar-smoking, blinged-out fat cat. Shown attached to the carriage is "Judge Winston's letter", dated 1890, which solicits White's political support by requesting that he put in a good word for Winston at the Judicial Convention. The foreground displays the sign: "A sample of Democratic white supremacy in North Carolina. Judge Winston's dream of riding the district with George H. White, the Negro of 'inflooence'."
Subject-Topic: Political campaigns; Elections; Politics and government; African Americans--History; Race relations; Manners and customs; Transportation;
Type-DCMI: Text; Still Image;
Type-AAT: broadsides;
Identifier-DukeID: bdsnc071894

Spatial 18:
Spatial 19:
Spatial 20:
Spatial 21:
Spatial 22:
Spatial 23:
Spatial 24:
Date: 1887-05-02
Description: Advertisement for White Bros., suppliers of building materials in "Mebbane, N. C.", who have available "everything you wish made out of wood...", including: "heart pine 4 inch gauged shingle..., and "...sawed or turned balusters". They also have in stock "lime, glass, paints, oils, nails, sash-weights, and cord, blind hinges, and frame pulleys" and will deliver if you live in "Caswell, Person, Granville and adjoining counties" and can't make it to the factory. A large hand pointing to the word "Build!" illustrates the broadside.

Spatial 24:
Date: 1882.0
Description: Broadside published by several leading citizens of Durham opposed to the levying of a property tax to establish a graded school system in place of public schools, arguing that the act must "have taxes divided pro rata between races" to avoid discrimination. Signed A. K. and J. N. Umstead, W. Duke and sons, Wm. Mangum, J. C. and M. A. Angier, E. J. Parrish, and others.

Spatial 24:
Date: 1860; 1861; 1862; 1863; 1864; 1865; 1866; 1867; 1868; 1869; 1870; 1871; 1872; 1873; 1874; 1875; 1876; 1877; 1878; 1879
Description: Broadside, circa 1860s-1870s, listing steamboats and routes operated along the Mississippi River, Ohio River, and tributaries by the Atlantic and Mississippi Steamship Company of New Orleans. Destinations include Cairo, St. Louis, Louisville, Yazoo City, Little Rock, Eastport, Nashville, Paducah, Mt. Vernon, Evansville, New Albany, Cincinnati, St. Paul, and St. Joseph. Steamers listed include: W.R. Arthur, Ruth, Atlantic, Ida Handy, City of Memphis, Julia, Mississippi, Mollie Able, Luminary, Edw. Walsh, Luna, Missouri, Olive Branch, Mary E. Forsyth, Hannibal, Niagara, Continental, Pauline Carroll, Ben Stickney, J.C. Swon, W.R. Carter, and Leviathan.

Spatial 18:
Spatial 19:
Spatial 20:
Spatial 21:
Spatial 22:
Spatial 23:
Spatial 24:
Date: 1868-10
Description: One-page announcement from the Scottish American Journal of the erection of a monument in Aberdeen in memory of the Clan Laurin, which had been destroyed by a "banditti of indendiarists" from Glendochart in 1558. The monument had been built by Daniel Maclaurin of St. John's Wood, London.

Date: 1860-05-07
Description: Report of Committee on Commerce in the proceedings of the May 7th, 1860 meeting of the Baltimore Board of Trade. Discusses the defects, especially in regard to duties and tariffs, of a "bill of Mr. Morrill of the Committee of Ways and Means, of the House of Representatives." Also proposes the establishment at Washington of a Bureau of Commerce.

Title: Battle of New Orleans
Country: United States
State: Louisiana
County: Orleans Parish (La.)
City: New Orleans (La.)
Spatial 5:
Spatial 6:
Spatial 7:
Spatial 8:
Spatial 9:
Spatial 10:
Spatial 11:
Spatial 12:
Spatial 13:
Spatial 14:
Spatial 15:
Spatial 16:
Spatial 17:
Spatial 18:
Spatial 19:
Spatial 20:
Spatial 21:
Spatial 22:
Spatial 23:
Spatial 24:
Date: 1815-01-15
Description: Description of Battle of New Orleans, final battle in War of 1812, concentrating on events between Dec. 23, 1814, and Jan. 9, 1815. At beginning: "Extra (by Authority). Friend of the Laws. New-Orleans, Sunday, January 15, 1815." "The result of this brilliant affair is unparalelled in the history of war--the enemy have lost in killed, wounded, and prisoners, not less than 2600 men; their commander in chief, sir Edward Packenham, killed; generals Gibbs and Keene wounded, and a great proportion of their most distinguished officers either killed, taken or wounded; while on our part, extraordinary as the fact may appear, we have lost only 13 in killed and wounded."
Subject-Topic: United States--History--War of 1812; War
Type-DCMI: Text
Type-AAT: broadsides
Identifier-DukeID: bdsla10558
Source: Broadsides and Ephemera Collection
Folder: LA1
Extent: 1 scan
Digital Collection: Broadsides and Ephemera Collection

Spatial 23:
Spatial 24:
Date: 1892-08-29
Description: Advertisement for the Belwood Institute "under the auspices of Trinity College, Durham." The three instructors: "J. P. Rodgers, B. D., Principal; Miss Mittie Cranford, assistant; Mrs. L. J. Hoyle, teacher of music" are listed, and the ten-month session rates for primary, intermediate, or advanced studies are stated as $1.00, $2.00, and $3.00 respectively. The institute is located "in one of the healthiest sections of the state, thirteen miles from the town of Shelby, near the foot of the mountains."

Title: Black man to black men
Country: United States
State: Tennessee
County: Georgia
City: Lowndes County (Ga.)
Spatial 5:
Spatial 6:
Spatial 7:
Spatial 8:
Spatial 9:
Spatial 10:
Spatial 11:
Spatial 12:
Spatial 13:
Spatial 14:
Spatial 15:
Spatial 16:
Spatial 17:
Spatial 18:
Spatial 19:
Spatial 20:
Spatial 21:
Spatial 22:
Spatial 23:
Spatial 24:
Date: 1865.0
Description: Single-page address titled "A Black Man to Black Men, an Address to the Freedmen of Tennessee and the Southern States," by Joseph E. Williams, "published by the order of the Executive Committee of the Constitutional Union Party of Lowndes Co." Address urges black men to reject the policies of Tennessee Governor Brownlow and other Radical Republicans, and stand instead with President Johnson and the Conservatives: "The Radicals are mainly office seekers who are seeking to bring on a conflict between us and the Southern people that they may become rich upon the spoils of a ruined people, a fallen republic and a bankrupt government."
Subject-Topic: Reconstruction (U.S. history, 1865-1877); African Americans--History; Race relations; Political campaigns; Politics and government;
Type-DCMI: Text
Type-AAT: broadsides; circular letters;
Identifier-DukeID: bdstn022973

Country: United States
State: Massachusetts
County: Middlesex County (Mass.)
City: Boston (Mass.)
Spatial 5:
Spatial 6:
Spatial 7:
Spatial 8:
Spatial 9:
Spatial 10:
Spatial 11:
Spatial 12:
Spatial 13:
Spatial 14:
Spatial 15:
Spatial 16:
Spatial 17:
Spatial 18:
Spatial 19:
Spatial 20:
Spatial 21:
Spatial 22:
Spatial 23:
Spatial 24:
Date: 1863-11-02
Description: Advertisement for performance of 3-act play "Camilla's husband" by Watts Phillips. Acting and stage manager, and director, E. F. Keach. Original overture and incidental music composed by Julius Eichberg. Cast includes: Sir Philip Hailstone, Sir James Hailstone, and Sir Tom Kendall. Also, a new farce entitled "Cousin Tom" opens each performance of the play.

Title: Bounty! To the colored soldiers in Kentucky
Country: United States
State: Kentucky
County:
City:
Spatial 5:
Spatial 6:
Spatial 7:
Spatial 8:
Spatial 9:
Spatial 10:
Spatial 11:
Spatial 12:
Spatial 13:
Spatial 14:
Spatial 15:
Spatial 16:
Spatial 17:
Spatial 18:
Spatial 19:
Spatial 20:
Spatial 21:
Spatial 22:
Spatial 23:
Spatial 24:
Date: 1870-09-17
Description: Broadside from Bureau of Refugees, Freedmen and Abandon Lands, Office of Disbursing Officer: "To the colored soldiers in Kentucky: I have in my possession a large number of bounties due colored soldiers and their heirs. The whereabouts of the claimants are unknown to me, because they have changed their residence since giving their address to their claim agents. I have accordingly determined to go myself, or send an agent, to each principal point in the state, with all the bounties entrusted to me for payment." Includes list of cities and towns where bounties will be distributed. Signed Ben P. Runkle, dated Sept. 17, 1870.
Subject-Topic: African Americans--History; Military campaigns; United States--History--Civil War, 1861-1865
Type-DCMI: Text
Type-AAT: broadsides
Identifier-DukeID: bdsky20509

Date: 1860; 1861; 1862; 1863; 1864; 1865
Description: Broadside distributed in Missouri featuring a political satire concerning preservation of the Union, written in a strongly colloquial, minstrel style: "What! Disolve de Onion? Make paper-rags ob de Stripes and Stars? Roast de American Eagle for a Secession oyster supper?"

Title: Burley tobacco growers strong for cutout
Country: United States
State: Kentucky
County: Fayette County (Ky.)
City: Lexington (Ky.)
Spatial 5:
Spatial 6:
Spatial 7:
Spatial 8:
Spatial 9:
Spatial 10:
Spatial 11:
Spatial 12:
Spatial 13:
Spatial 14:
Spatial 15:
Spatial 16:
Spatial 17:
Spatial 18:
Spatial 19:
Spatial 20:
Spatial 21:
Spatial 22:
Spatial 23:
Spatial 24:
Date: 1921-01-10T00:00:00Z
Description: Report of remarks given by U.S. Representative J. Campbell Cantrill after a convention of tobacco growers in Lexington, Kentucky voted to plant no tobacco in 1921 and to suspend tobacco sales in Kentucky until after May 1, 1921. Cantrill notes the collapse of the world tobacco market and its affect on tobacco growers. Report distributed by Edmondson and Powell Co.
Subject-Topic: Agriculture; Commerce; Politics and government

Type-AAT: broadsides

Spatial 14:

Spatial 16:
Spatial 17:
Spatial 18:
Spatial 19:
Spatial 20:
Spatial 21:
Spatial 22:
Spatial 23:
Spatial 24:
Date: 1801-02-17
Description: To the editors of the Times, This moment the election is decided, Morris, from Vermont, absented himself, so that Vermont was for Jefferson. The four members from Maryland, who had voted for Burr, put in blank tickets. The result was then ten for Jefferson. I hope you will have the cannon out to announce the news.
Subject-Topic: Elections; Politics and government
Type-DCMI: Text
Type-AAT: ephemera

Spatial 24:
Date: 1812-08-05
Description: One-paged proclamation by Baltimore mayor Edward Johnson issuing a curfew for "peaceable well disposed citizens," ordering them to stay home after 8:00pm until the riots are over. He adds that "those who are in the streets only as spectators, will subject themselves to the danger of suffering with the guilty."

Date: 1894.0
Description: Advertisement for C. E. Gordon's Wilmington, North Carolina store, which appears to specialize in selling underwear and "gent's furnishings" including French balbriggan". The broadside also features the lyrics of four songs: "Why did they dig Ma's grave so deep"; "50 cents" and "I'se gwine back to Dixie"; "Every day'l be Sunday by-and-by" which are in stereotypical Negro dialect.

Title: Can any reasonable man longer doubt?
Country: United States
State: North Carolina
County: New Hanover County (N.C.)
City: Wilmington (N.C.)
Spatial 5:
Spatial 6:
Spatial 7:
Spatial 8:
Spatial 9:
Spatial 10:
Spatial 11:
Spatial 12:
Spatial 13:
Spatial 14:
Spatial 15:
Spatial 16:
Spatial 17:
Spatial 18:
Spatial 19:
Spatial 20:
Spatial 21:
Spatial 22:
Spatial 23:
Spatial 24:
Date: 1898.0
Description: Second letter in three weeks from (Republican) Wilmington Postmaster W. H. Chadbourn to Senator J. C. Pritchard, attempting to correct the false impression left by his first letter, which was "published prominently in every fusionist newspaper in the state, and has been issued as a campaign document...of both the Republican and Populist state committees", regarding the "negroization" of Wilmington. "...Property owners, taxpayers and business men seriously object" to the number of Negroes holding public office in New Hanover County, and "there now exists here the most intense feeling against any sort of negro domination" and many feel that "a race conflict is imminent..."
Subject-Topic: Race relations; African Americans--History; Politics and government; Political campaigns; Elections;
Type-DCMI: Text
Type-AAT: broadsides;
Identifier-DukeID: bdsnc061808
Source: Broadsides and Ephemera Collection
Folder: NC6
Extent: 1 scan
Digital Collection: Broadsides and Ephemera Collection

Spatial 13:

Spatial 16:
Spatial 17:
Spatial 18:
Spatial 19:
Spatial 20:
Spatial 21:
Spatial 22:
Spatial 23:
Spatial 24:
Date: 1934.0
Description: Open letter from Huey P. Long to citizens of New Orleans, on 1934 mayoral race. Candidates: incumbent T. Semmes Walmsley; Francis Williams; and John Klorer, endorsed by Long. "Walmsley, Williams, the Times-Picayune, Daily States, and Item have praised Huey P. Long to the sky; some of them say Walmsley is unfit, and some say that Williams is an anarchist and a rioter, but everyone has said that Klorer is honest, reliable and competent and none deny that now."
Subject-Topic: Political campaigns; Elections
Type-DCMI: Text
Type-AAT: circular letters

Spatial 10:
Spatial 11:
Spatial 12:
Spatial 13:
Spatial 14:
Spatial 15:
Spatial 16:
Spatial 17:
Spatial 18:
Spatial 19:
Spatial 20:
Spatial 21:
Spatial 22:
Spatial 23:
Spatial 24:
Date: 1873.0
Description: Brochure on establishment of principal offices in the South, located in Charlotte and Goldsboro, North Carolina, of Philadelphia's Bellevue Institute and Cancer Infirmary. To be treated: "cancers, tumors, and ulcers, together with all forms of chronic, obscure, and difficult diseases ... The remedies as used heretofore in the treatment of cancer will be mainly Dr. Kline's Celebrated Cancer Antidotes ... in nearly all cases, every particle, root and fibre belonging to it is thus destroyed without the use of the knife, without caustic, eating or burning medicines, and without the loss of blood." Includes testimonials and list of local "patients cured."
Subject-Topic: Health and hygiene; Advertising;
Type-DCMI: Text
Type-AAT: brochures; advertisements;

Title: Captions of the laws enacted by the General Assembly of North Carolina at its session in 1830-31
Country: United States
State: North Carolina
County:
City:
Spatial 5:
Spatial 6:
Spatial 7:
Spatial 8:
Spatial 9:
Spatial 10:
Spatial 11:
Spatial 12:
Spatial 13:
Spatial 14:
Spatial 15:
Spatial 16:
Spatial 17:
Spatial 18:
Spatial 19:
Spatial 20:
Spatial 21:
Spatial 22:
Spatial 23:
Spatial 24:
Date: 1831.0
Description: Summary of public acts, private acts, and resolution of 1830-31 North Carolina General Assembly session. Highlights: term limits; prohibition on teaching slaves to read or write; militia laws; railroads; loan to University of North Carolina; shipwrecks; "gaming" and trading with slaves; many local laws.
Subject-Topic: Politics and government; Slavery; Race relations; Commerce; Education;

Title: Carriers' address to the patrons of the Natchez Daily Free Trader
Country: United States
State: Mississippi
County: Adams County (Miss.)
City: Natchez (Miss.)
Spatial 5:
Spatial 6:
Spatial 7:
Spatial 8:
Spatial 9:
Spatial 10:
Spatial 11:
Spatial 12:
Spatial 13:
Spatial 14:
Spatial 15:
Spatial 16:
Spatial 17:
Spatial 18:
Spatial 19:
Spatial 20:
Spatial 21:
Spatial 22:
Spatial 23:
Spatial 24:
Date: 1861-01-01
Description: New Year's Day address in the form of a poem from the carriers of the Natchez Daily Free Trader to patrons of the newspaper. "Time notches on each passing year Deeds noble and sublime; It fills the land with glory bright And darkens it with crime." State's rights and the secession of southern states from the Union is dwelt upon, as Southern men prepare to "drive that good Secession steel Right through the monster's head." Along the way through the coming year, "The Carrier Boy goes boldly along His path of duty plain. In all weather, fair and foul, he trudges on his way, Blessing each home with knowledge good To bear men through the day."
Subject-Topic: United States--History--Civil War, 1861-1865; Advertising; Speeches, addresses, etc.; Manners and customs; Politics and government
Type-DCMI: Text
Type-AAT: broadsides
Identifier-DukeID: bdsms21241

Extent: 1 scan

Spatial 24:
Date: 1878-01-01
Description: Single-page broadside of a poem titled "Carrier's Address to the Patrons of the Shepherdstown Register," with the text of the poem in two columns and local advertisements in a third column: " I have wearied my brain with historical talk, I have traveled many miles in my twelve months' walk, I have kept you advised of the news of the day, I hope I deserve it--reward me I pray."

Spatial 23:

Country: United States
State: North Carolina
County: Craven County (N.C.)
City: New Bern (N.C.)
Spatial 5:
Spatial 6:

Spatial 9:
Spatial 10:

Spatial 12:
Spatial 13:

Spatial 16:
Spatial 17:
Spatial 18:
Spatial 19:
Spatial 20:
Spatial 21:
Spatial 22:
Spatial 23:
Spatial 24:
Date: 1885; 1886; 1887; 1888; 1889; 1890; 1891; 1892; 1893; 1894; 1895; 1896; 1897; 1898; 1899; 1900; 1901; 1902; 1903; 1904; 1905; 1906; 1907; 1908; 1909; 1910
Description: Four-page pamphlet issued by William H. Oliver, describing the Confederate memorial at Cedar Grove Cemetery and the 10th of May tribute, "memorable as the anniversary of the death of the lamented Stonewall Jackson," given to honor the Confederate dead. Contains a list of "Confederate Officers, Soldiers, and Surgeons" buried at the cemetery and an illustration of the monument.
Subject-Topic: Manners and customs; United States--History--Civil War, 1861-1865; Military campaigns;

Title: Celebrated sun light oil
Country: United States
State: Michigan
County: Calhoun County (Mich.)
City: Marshall (Mich.)
Spatial 5:
Spatial 6:
Spatial 7:
Spatial 8:
Spatial 9:
Spatial 10:
Spatial 11:
Spatial 12:
Spatial 13:
Spatial 14:
Spatial 15:
Spatial 16:
Spatial 17:
Spatial 18:
Spatial 19:
Spatial 20:
Spatial 21:
Spatial 22:
Spatial 23:
Spatial 24:
Date: 1870.0
Description: Facsimile of an advertisement, circa 1870, for Dr. Culver's Celebrated Sun Light Oil. "M. Wagner & Co. are sole proprietors for the United States and Canadas. Sold only by their authorized agents. Costs but twenty cents per gallon to manufacture, and can be manufactured anywhere in the United States. This wonderful oil, which is about to take the place of kerosene and other burning fluids, is composed of materials which can be obtained in any country village. Can be made without the aid of machinery, by simply mixing the ingredients together. It has no offensive smell whatever, and is warranted to be non explosive."
Subject-Topic: Commerce; Advertising
Type-DCMI: Text
Type-AAT: broadsides; advertisements

Spatial 18:
Spatial 19:
Spatial 20:
Spatial 21:
Spatial 22:
Spatial 23:
Spatial 24:
Date: 1839-07-01
Description: Certificate for Internal Improvement stock with redemption coupons, issued July 1, 1839 in Springfield, Ill. Certificate entitles the bearer to 6 percent annual interest on a deposit of 100 pounds sterling.

Spatial 21:
Spatial 22:
Spatial 23:
Spatial 24:
Date: 1860-03-06
Description: Single-sided certificate from Wood, Eddy & Co. publishing the numbers drawn for the "state of Delaware lottery, extra class no. 111, for 1860". Notice at bottom of certificate states that "Drawn Numbers of the State of Delaware Lotteries are published by the Commissioners, in the New-York Times and New-York Herald."

Spatial 21:
Spatial 22:
Spatial 23:
Spatial 24:
Date: 1853-10
Description: One-page certificate indicating life membership of Catherine Campbell in the Missionary Society of the Methodist Episcopal Church, South. The certificate contains a detailed engraving by Charles A. Jewett of a child, a lion, lambs,and missionaries preaching to Native Americans and African-American slaves.

Spatial 23:
Spatial 24:
Date: 1870; 1871; 1872; 1873; 1874; 1875; 1876; 1877; 1878; 1879
Description: Biographical essay about Louisiana writer Chahta-Ima, born Adrien Rouquette, 1813-1887. He lived his later life with Choctaw Indians and came to be viewed as part of their community. In French. Undated; 1870s?

Spatial 21:
Spatial 22:
Spatial 23:
Spatial 24:
Date: 1864-07
Description: Poem by Edwin N. Andrews, Chaplain of the 2nd Division New Jersey Calvary, addressed to the Union soldiers of the 2nd New Jersey, 19th Pennsylvania, 4th Missouri, 7th Indiana and 1st Mississippi Calvary Regiments. Reverse side has lyrics to "Columbia, the Gem of the Ocean," "Battle Cry of Freedom," "America," "Star-Spangled Banner," "Marching Along," "Sweet Hour of Prayer," and Just before the Battle, Mother."

Title: Chaplain's circular for Dept. of Michigan Grand Army of the Republic
Country: United States
State: Michigan
County: Delta County (Mich.)
City: Escanaba (Mich.)
Spatial 5:
Spatial 6:
Spatial 7:
Spatial 8:
Spatial 9:
Spatial 10:
Spatial 11:
Spatial 12:
Spatial 13:
Spatial 14:
Spatial 15:
Spatial 16:
Spatial 17:
Spatial 18:
Spatial 19:
Spatial 20:
Spatial 21:
Spatial 22:
Spatial 23:
Spatial 24:
Date: 1887-04-20
Description: Circular letter from H. W. Thompson, Chaplain of the Department of Michigan Grand Army of the Republic, announcing the observance of May 30th as Memorial Day. He calls on the Department of Michigan, members of the Woman's Relief Corps, and the Camps of the Sons of Veterans to assemble and participate in "the beautiful services provided by the Grand Army." The chaplain recommends inviting children to the services, where they may learn "the principles of loyalty and patriotism," and may "take up the loving task...of scattering flowers over the graves of our Nation's patriots, and commemorating their lives and deeds."
Subject-Topic: Anniversaries; Military campaigns; Fraternal organizations
Type-DCMI: Text
Type-AAT: circular letters
Identifier-DukeID: bdsmi11100
Source: Broadsides and Ephemera Collection
Folder: MI1

Title: Cheap excursion, twelve dollars to Cincinnati, Ohio, and return
Country: United States
State: Louisiana
County: Ohio
City: Orleans Parish (La.)
Spatial 5: Hamilton County (Ohio)
Spatial 6: New Orleans (La.)
Spatial 7: Cincinnati (Ohio)
Spatial 8:
Spatial 9:
Spatial 10:
Spatial 11:
Spatial 12:
Spatial 13:
Spatial 14:
Spatial 15:
Spatial 16:
Spatial 17:
Spatial 18:
Spatial 19:
Spatial 20:
Spatial 21:
Spatial 22:
Spatial 23:
Spatial 24:
Date: 1895.0
Description: Single-sided broadside advertising train tickets from New Orleans and vicinity to Cincinnati "via Queen & Crescent Route, via Lookout Mountain, August 22. Good going on Train No. 2 leaving New Orleans 3:20 p.m., August 22, with privilege of returning on all regular trains within ten (10) days limit. This rate applies from New Orleans, Slidell, Nicolson, Poplarville, Purvis, Hattiesburg, Ellisville." Handwritten names and addresses on back. Circa 1895.
Subject-Topic: Transportation; Advertising
Type-DCMI: Text
Type-AAT: broadsides; advertisements

Spatial 23:
Spatial 24:
Date: 1857-04-04
Description: Single-page campaign circular issued by Jackson McDowell announcing his intention to run for legislative office: "I come not before you as one laboring under the maddened impulse of party prejudice, or as one seeking good at the expense of my country's welfare, or that would pluck a laurel from the brow of the humblest citizen for my own personal good; but as one, if I know my own heart, that desires to serve my country."

Date: 1844.0

Scoville, Secretary of the Calhoun Central Committee, to establish county committees in each state "friendly to the elevation of Mr. Calhoun". Spatial 23:
Spatial 24:
Date: 1865-07-25
Description: Circular letter signed by Lewis E. Parsons, provisional governor of Alabama, with header Executive Department of Alabama, Montgomery, Alabama, July 25, 1865. Asks about participation in the war, particularly about persecution of those "disloyal to the Confederate States of America." Final questions include "Will you be a peaceable and loyal citizen in the future?"

Date: 1859-07-01
Description: Single-page circular letter from the "Executive Committee for the Middle Division of Tennessee," addressed to "the rank and file of the Whig and American parties" throughout Tennessee, asking for campaign work and reports on "the condition of our cause in your county or vicinity." Title: Circular letter regarding free right to vote bill
Country: United States
State: Louisiana
County: Orleans Parish (La.)
City: New Orleans (La.)
Spatial 5:
Spatial 6:
Spatial 7:
Spatial 8:
Spatial 9:
Spatial 10:
Spatial 11:
Spatial 12:
Spatial 13:
Spatial 14:
Spatial 15:
Spatial 16:
Spatial 17:
Spatial 18:
Spatial 19:
Spatial 20:
Spatial 21:
Spatial 22:
Spatial 23:
Spatial 24:
Date: 1934.0
Description: One-sided circular letter from 1934, co-written by Huey P. Long (U.S. Senator) and O. K. Allen (Governor). The purpose seeks to gain support for the poll tax bill which needs approval by the Louisiana House of Representatives. The bill was previously approved by the State Senate. Allen and Long charge that the "ringsters" and "lying newspapers" are conspiring to ensure the House doesn't approve the measure, which will mean the "common" people will have to continue paying a poll tax in order to vote.
Subject-Topic: Politics and government
Type-DCMI: Text
Type-AAT: circular letters
Identifier-DukeID: bdsla50718
Source: Broadsides and Ephemera Collection
Folder: LA5
Extent: 1 scan
Digital Collection: Broadsides and Ephemera Collection

Spatial 23:
Spatial 24:
Date: 1818-12-25
Description: Circular letter from state representatives William P. Dobsom, Solomon Graves, and H.P. Poindexter, on recent activities of state legislature, 1818. Highlights: reform of judicial system and salary of judges; banking capital; improving navigability of state rivers; establishment of Jonesville Academy; trials of slaves; compensation of Attorney General; giving Superior Courts of state ability to emancipate slaves.

Title: Circular letter, Elijah M. Haines to state governors, 1867
Country: United States
State: Illinois
County: Lake County (Ill.)
City: Chicago (Ill.)
Spatial 5:

Spatial 8:
Spatial 9:

Spatial 17:
Spatial 18:
Spatial 19:
Spatial 20:
Spatial 21:
Spatial 22:
Spatial 23:
Spatial 24:
Date: 1867-01-08
Description: Letter, with attachments, from Elijah M. Haines of Illinois to state governors regarding reconstruction and encouraging development and manufacturing in the southern states. Haines argues that states should adopt local self-government laws similar to the Township Organization Laws of Illinois and Wisconsin. Attached is three-page document titled: Local Self-Government: The True Policy on the Part of the Southern States for Restoration.
Subject-Topic: Politics and government

Type-AAT: circular letters

Title: Circular regulating plantations in Mississippi during Civil War
Country: United States
State: Mississippi
County:
City:
Spatial 5:
Spatial 6:
Spatial 7:
Spatial 8:
Spatial 9:
Spatial 10:
Spatial 11:
Spatial 12:
Spatial 13:
Spatial 14:
Spatial 15:
Spatial 16:
Spatial 17:
Spatial 18:
Spatial 19:
Spatial 20:
Spatial 21:
Spatial 22:
Spatial 23:
Spatial 24:
Date: 1863-10-27
Description: Circular from L. Thomas, adjutant general, by order of the Secretary of War, on control of plantations in Mississippi during Civil War. "The primary objects are to line the banks of the Mississippi River with a loyal population, and to give aid in securing the uninterrupted navigation of the river; at the same time, to give employment to the freed negroes whereby they may earn wages and become self-supporting." Also mentions right of U.S. government to seize property of disloyal persons and redistribute to loyal citizens. "Men of doubted loyalty, if permitted to cultivate their plantations, will be required to take as a partner a loyal citizen." Issued in Natchez.
Subject-Topic: United States--History--Civil War, 1861-1865; Slavery; Agriculture; Commerce
Type-DCMI: Text
Type-AAT: circular letters
Identifier-DukeID: bdsms21224
Source: Broadsides and Ephemera Collection
Folder: MS2
Extent: 1 scan
Digital Collection: Broadsides and Ephemera Collection

Spatial 21:
Spatial 22:
Spatial 23:
Spatial 24:
Date: 1870-09-22
Description: 2-page circular letter from the Board of County School Commissioners to the Carroll County, Md. public schools. The letter outlines policies regarding teacher's salaries, classroom size, admission, e.g. "...pupils between the ages of six and twenty-one years are by law entitled to admission into the public schools", cost of textbooks, etc. Page 2 contains "Rules relating to pupils" and a caution to teachers to resist ordering too many classroom textbooks.

Title: Circular, Bureau of Ordnance, Navy Department
Country: United States
State: District of Columbia
County: District of Columbia
City: Washington (D.C.)
Spatial 5:
Spatial 6:
Spatial 7:
Spatial 8:
Spatial 9:
Spatial 10:
Spatial 11:
Spatial 12:
Spatial 13:
Spatial 14:
Spatial 15:
Spatial 16:
Spatial 17:
Spatial 18:
Spatial 19:
Spatial 20:
Spatial 21:
Spatial 22:
Spatial 23:
Spatial 24:
Date: 1863-09-26
Description: 1-page circular concerning use and stowage of "powder and loaded shells in Magazines and Shell-rooms, ashore and afloat." As a precaution against explosions, modified regulations call for dispensing "entirely with the use of slippers made of either India rubber or woolen..." and providing "slippers made wholly of buckskin or cotton canvas."
Subject-Topic: United States--History--Civil War, 1861-1865; Military campaigns; Manners and customs
Type-DCMI: Text
Type-AAT: circular letters

Title: Circular, to the citizens of the 10th Congressional District in North Carolina, composed of the counties of Chatham, Randolph, Davidson, and Rowan
Country: United States
State: North Carolina
County: Chatham County (N.C.)
City: Davidson County (N.C.)
Spatial 5: Rowan County (N.C.)
Spatial 6: Randolph County (N.C.)
Spatial 7: South America
Spatial 8: Greece;
Spatial 9:
Spatial 10:
Spatial 11:
Spatial 12:
Spatial 13:
Spatial 14:
Spatial 15:
Spatial 16:
Spatial 17:
Spatial 18:
Spatial 19:
Spatial 20:
Spatial 21:
Spatial 22:
Spatial 23:
Spatial 24:
Date: 1824-05-15
Description: Circular from U.S. congress representative John Long, Jr., of North Carolina, on activities of recently closed 18th Congress, 1824. Highlights: public finance and treasury; independence of Greece; "proposition to announce to the world that we would protect South America or espouse her quarrel under all circumstances of interference by Europeans to prevent the establishment of liberty in that part of our hemisphere"; support for William H. Crawford in upcoming presidential election.
Subject-Topic: Politics and government; Commerce;
Type-DCMI: Text
Type-AAT: circular letters;
Identifier-DukeID: bdsnc011609

Spatial 24:
Date: 1872.0
Description: Four-page, double-sided circular letter from "attorney at law and solicitor of claims" James Fullerton, advertising his services for prosecuting "southern claims for supplies used by the U.S. Army" during the Civil War. "Loyal citizens of the southern states, whose property was appropriated for military purposes or who furnished supplies for which they have not yet received compensation should apply at once."

Title: Clark is charged with falsifying the history.
Country: United States
State: North Carolina
County: Wake County (N.C.)
City: Raleigh (N.C.)
Spatial 5:
Spatial 6:
Spatial 7:
Spatial 8:
Spatial 9:
Spatial 10:
Spatial 11:
Spatial 12:
Spatial 13:
Spatial 14:
Spatial 15:
Spatial 16:
Spatial 17:
Spatial 18:
Spatial 19:
Spatial 20:
Spatial 21:
Spatial 22:
Spatial 23:
Spatial 24:
Date: 1902-07
Description: Open letter to F. M. Simmons, Senator, and Chairmen State Democratic Committee, from Col. W. F. Beasley, published in the July 13, 1902 Raleigh Post. The letter claims that Walter Clark falsified information as editor of "History of the North Carolina Regiments", elevating his position to "Lt.-Col. 70th N.C. Troops" while denigrating the records and character of others, and due to this, should not be considered worthy of nomination for Chief Justice of the North Carolina Supreme Court.
Subject-Topic: United States--History--Civil War, 1861-1865; Elections; Political campaigns; Politics and government; Race relations; African Americans--History;
Type-DCMI: Text
Type-AAT: newspaper clippings; circular letters; broadsides;

Spatial 23:
Spatial 24:
Date: 1865-11
Description: Four-page brochure for Bryant, Stratton & Felton's Cleveland Business College and Telegraphic Institute, "one of a chain of Thirty-five similar Institutions, situated in every large Commerical Center in the country." Courses taught include "the Science of Accounts," commercial law, book-keeping, "Spencerian Penmanship," and telegraph operating.

Spatial 18:
Spatial 19:
Spatial 20:
Spatial 21:
Spatial 22:
Spatial 23:
Spatial 24:
Date: 1813-09-02
Description: Leaflet advertising Cohen's Lottery & Exchange Office's "Baltimore Hospital Lottery." The front page lists the monetary prizes and rules. The second page provides "Wharton's, Nicklin's and Cohen's list of the sixty-seventh day's drawing of the Medical College Lottery," dated Sept. 2, 1813. The last page shows that the leaflet was mailed as a postmark is visible. It was sent to Samuel Hannah, Esq. of Rough Creek Church, Va.

Title: Cole Lectures
Country: United States
State: Missouri
County: Tennessee
City: Boone County (Mo.)
Spatial 5: Davidson County (Tenn.)
Spatial 6: Columbia (Mo.)
Spatial 7: Nashville (Tenn.)
Spatial 8:
Spatial 9:
Spatial 10:
Spatial 11:
Spatial 12:
Spatial 13:
Spatial 14:
Spatial 15:
Spatial 16:
Spatial 17:
Spatial 18:
Spatial 19:
Spatial 20:
Spatial 21:
Spatial 22:
Spatial 23:
Spatial 24:
Date: 1929-04
Description: Four-page leaflet on the Cole Lectures for 1929, sponsored by the faculty of the School of Religion at Vanderbilt University. The leaflet includes an open invitation from the faculty inviting people to hear guest speaker, Charles Abram Ellwood, Ph.D., give the Cole Lectures with the theme "Man's Social Destiny." Ellwood was scheduled to give the lectures from April 21-26, 1929. At this time, Ellwood is a sociology professor at the Univ. of Missouri. Page three provides the titles of each lecture, the date/time and location. The fourth page just has the words "Cole Lectures" and "1929" on it.
Subject-Topic: Education
Type-DCMI: Text
Type-AAT: leaflets
Identifier-DukeID: bdsmo21186
Source: Broadsides and Ephemera Collection
Folder: MO2
Extent: 4 scans
Digital Collection: Broadsides and Ephemera Collection

Date: 1875.0
Description: Single-page circular letter from the State Board of Centennial Managers sent to appointees to county boards delegated "to collect and to forward to this office for Classification, Enumeration, &c. &c., samples...of all substances of value found in their county," and to secure "the aid of persons in every District of your county who are desirous to get their Minerals and Products into a market."

Date: 1876.0
Description: Single-page circular letter, issued by the Office of State Board of Centennial Managers for the U. S. Centennial International Exhibition, sent to appointees to local boards formed to assist with the collection of exhibition materials for West Virginia: "in order that our objects may, with the short time remaining, be more certainly accomplished, we deem it best to increase the number, and I have the honor of notifying you of your appointment on this Board by the State Board of Centennial Managers." Signed A. J. Sweeney, Chairman, and M. F. Maury, Director in Charge of Collection.

Spatial 24:
Date: 1863.0
Description: Broadside, circa 1863, listing names of officers and soldiers in Company A, 68th Regiment of Indiana Volunteers (Union). The company was mustered into service August 19, 1862 at Indianapolis, Ind., by Col. Carrington. Broadside includes a brief history of the company's activities during the Civil War.

Spatial 17:
Spatial 18:
Spatial 19:
Spatial 20:
Spatial 21:
Spatial 22:
Spatial 23:
Spatial 24:
Date: 1864-03-07
Description: Letter from N. M. Mann, "agent of the Western Sanitary Commission" to Rev. Dr. Eliot, acting president of the Commission, describing "affecting scenes and incidents" of the terrible "condition of the Negroes who came into Vicksburg with Sherman's Army". He makes an appeal for generous charitable contributions for the "Mississippi Valley Sanitary Fair for freedmen and refugees" needed to feed, clothe and care for them.

Title: Conditions upon which license to sell liquor is granted by the City of Wilmington, N. C.
Country: United States
State: North Carolina
County: New Hanover County (N.C.)
City: Wilmington (N.C.)
Spatial 5:
Spatial 6:
Spatial 7:
Spatial 8:
Spatial 9:
Spatial 10:
Spatial 11:
Spatial 12:
Spatial 13:
Spatial 14:
Spatial 15:
Spatial 16:
Spatial 17:
Spatial 18:
Spatial 19:
Spatial 20:
Spatial 21:
Spatial 22:
Spatial 23:
Spatial 24:
Date: 1903-06-22T00:00:00Z
Description: Ordinance for granting liquor licenses in Wilmington, N. C., adopted by the Board of Aldermen June 22nd, 1903, and signed by B. F. King, Clerk and Treasurer. The broadside outlines eleven conditions for granting liquor licenses, among them: "No woman shall enter any...place where intoxicating drinks are sold", except in "those places where groceries and liquors are sold together this shall not apply to the grocery department." Also, saloons cannot sell or give away liquor, nor sell meals on Sunday, and "curtains to all the windows of all saloons shall be raised on Sunday and no windows shall be stained or painted."
Subject-Topic: Commerce; Entertainment; Health and hygiene; Manners and customs; Politics and government; Women;
Type-DCMI: Text
Type-AAT: broadsides;
Identifier-DukeID: bdsnc071891
Source: Broadsides and Ephemera Collection
Folder: NC7
Extent: 1 scan
Digital Collection: Broadsides and Ephemera Collection

Country: United States
State: Mississippi
County:
City:
Spatial 5:

Spatial 7:
Spatial 8:
Spatial 9:
Spatial 10:
Spatial 11:
Spatial 12:

Spatial 14:
Spatial 15:
Spatial 16:
Spatial 17:
Spatial 18:
Spatial 19:
Spatial 20:
Spatial 21:
Spatial 22:
Spatial 23:
Spatial 24:
Date: 1865-05
Description: Broadside from circa May 1865 is an illustration titled "The Confederacy in Petticoats." It shows Jefferson Davis dressed in women's clothing, jumping over a fence while being pursued by two Union soldiers. Davis is shown with a knife in his right hand and a piece of luggage on the ground says "J. Davis Mexico." Also present in the illustration is a southern woman who says "Don't Irritate the "President" he might hurt somebody."
Subject-Topic: United States--History--Civil War, 1861-1865
Type-DCMI: Text
Type-AAT: broadsides

Title: Confederate Memorial Day!
Country: United States
State: North Carolina
County: Forsyth County (N.C.)
City: Winston-Salem (N.C.)
Spatial 5:
Spatial 6:
Spatial 7:
Spatial 8:
Spatial 9:
Spatial 10:
Spatial 11:
Spatial 12:
Spatial 13:
Spatial 14:
Spatial 15:
Spatial 16:
Spatial 17:
Spatial 18:
Spatial 19:
Spatial 20:
Spatial 21:
Spatial 22:
Spatial 23:
Spatial 24:
Date: 1896-05-09
Description: Program for 1896 celebration of Confederate Memorial Day, with order of exercises for the Norfleet Camp, No. 436 U.C.V. (United Confederate Veterans). The procession will begin at the "Armory of Forsyth Rifleman", where the "Davis School Band, Davis School Cadets, and Forsyth Riflemen" will form the line, to be joined by the veterans and sons of veterans, then the procession will continue on to the cemetery. After the grave decorating, prayer, military salute, and taps, the line will march back to the Armory where "lunch will be served by the good ladies of Winston-Salem." An image of a cannon and stack of fifteen cannon balls is printed at the top of the program.
Subject-Topic: United States--History--Civil War, 1861-1865; Entertainment; Exhibitions; Fraternal organizations; Manners and customs; Speeches, addresses, etc.; Education; Military campaigns; Politics and government; Women;
Type-DCMI: Text; Still Image;

Spatial 22:
Spatial 23:
Spatial 24:
Date: 1854; 1855; 1856; 1857
Description: Broadside of the founding constitution of the Fremont Club of Ashburnham, Massachusetts, a political organization opposed to measures "which we deem contrary to the spirit of the Constitution, and which are designed to extend and perpetuate Slavery," such as the Kansas-Nebraska Act of 1854, alluded to in the preamble.

Title: Constitution of the Presbyterian Education Society of Kentucky, 1828
Country: United States
State: Kentucky
County: Boyle County (Ky.)
City: Danville (Ky.)
Spatial 5:
Spatial 6:
Spatial 7:
Spatial 8:
Spatial 9:
Spatial 10:
Spatial 11:
Spatial 12:
Spatial 13:
Spatial 14:
Spatial 15:
Spatial 16:
Spatial 17:
Spatial 18:
Spatial 19:
Spatial 20:
Spatial 21:
Spatial 22:
Spatial 23:
Spatial 24:
Date: 1828.0
Description: Constitution outlines the purpose and organization of the Presbyterian Education Society of Kentucky--"to assist indigent and pious young men, destined for the gospel ministry, in acquiring an Academic and Theological education." Men were to be educated at Centre College in Danville, Ky. Attached is a letter from James K. Burch to Sidney Clay asking for his help in securing scholarships to the school and identifying students.
Subject-Topic: Education; Religion
Type-DCMI: Text
Type-AAT: broadsides; ephemera

Spatial 21:
Spatial 22:
Spatial 23:
Spatial 24:
Date: 1859-08-01
Description: 1-page circular letter to Postmasters announcing the resumption of construction on the Washington National Monument. As a means of fund-raising, the letter proposes to "request the Postmasters throughout the country to give aid to the enterprise, by placing boxes, within their respective offices, for the reception of contributions, and forwarding the returns to this place."

Date: 1912.0
Description: The North Carolina Historical Association approved the placement of a plaque commemorating the Mecklenburg Declaraion of Independence by the North Carolina Society of the Colonial Dames. The information was disputed, and Charles L. Van Noppen of Greensboro encouraged readers to protest.

Spatial 17:

Spatial 19:
Spatial 20:
Spatial 21:
Spatial 22:
Spatial 23:
Spatial 24:
Date:
Description: One page, undated broadside with a correspondence between a Rumseller and Diabolus. The rumseller proposes a partnership with the devil, asking for innocent men and women to be sent to his shops so that he might grow rich. He will return them to the devil as drunkards, paupers, and beggars. The devil accepts the proposal.

Date: 1838.0
Description: Single-page extra from the Tennessee Journal reproducing correspondence between the office of the Secretary of War and the Cherokee Nation during the closing months of 1837, concerning the Cherokee Delegation's desire to change the territorial boundaries requiring dislocation of the tribes under the 1836 Treaty of New Echota, and the government's refusal to alter the terms of removal.

Spatial 8:
Spatial 9:

Spatial 16:
Spatial 17:
Spatial 18:
Spatial 19:
Spatial 20:
Spatial 21:
Spatial 22:
Spatial 23:
Spatial 24:
Date:
Description: Advertisement for two pro-slavery works edited by E. N. Elliott, president of Planters' College of Mississippi. Includes a list of pro-slavery Senators and Representatives: Jas H. Hammond, Jefferson Davis, Robert Toomes, R. M. T. Hunter, James M. Mason, John Slidell, A. G. Brown, C. C. Clay Jr., Henry C. Burnett, Lucius Q. C. Lamar, Edward Bouligny, Milledge L. Bonham, Lucius J. Gartrell, Thomas C. Hindan, Thomas Ruffin, Andrew J. Hamilton, Alexander R. Bolter, John M. Landrum, Elbert S. Martin, Thomas S. Bocock, Lawrence M. Keitt, Thomas Hardeman Jr., George S. Hawkins, Sydenham Moore, Burton Craige, John H. Beagan, Thomas G. Davidson, Muscoe R. H. Garnett, Reuben Davis, Henry A. Edmundson, and William Porcher Miles.

Title: Cotton to equalize supply and demand
Country: United States
State: North Carolina
County: Mecklenburg County (N.C.)
City: Charlotte (N.C.)
Spatial 5:
Spatial 6:
Spatial 7:
Spatial 8:
Spatial 9:
Spatial 10:
Spatial 11:
Spatial 12:
Spatial 13:
Spatial 14:
Spatial 15:
Spatial 16:
Spatial 17:
Spatial 18:
Spatial 19:
Spatial 20:
Spatial 21:
Spatial 22:
Spatial 23:
Spatial 24:
Date: 1905.0
Description: Plan, copyrighted 1905, from D. A. Tompkins to "issue a certificate on cotton which would stand good for its safe storage and also for the grade..., character of the cotton...accurately determined...by an expert. The certificate would "facilitate trading in cotton because specifications could be copied and forwarded to a number of different people to show what cotton was for sale. When a trade was made the certificate could be forwarded through the banks."
Subject-Topic: Agriculture; Commerce;
Type-DCMI: Text
Type-AAT: broadsides;
Identifier-DukeID: bdsnc071897
Source: Broadsides and Ephemera Collection
Folder: NC7
Extent: 1 scan
Digital Collection: Broadsides and Ephemera Collection
Title: Cotton vs. currency: Ought the cotton trade to be opened?
Country: United States
State: Massachusetts
County: Middlesex County (Mass.)
City: Boston (Mass.)
Spatial 5:
Spatial 6:
Spatial 7:
Spatial 8:
Spatial 9:
Spatial 10:
Spatial 11:
Spatial 12:
Spatial 13:
Spatial 14:
Spatial 15:
Spatial 16:
Spatial 17:
Spatial 18:
Spatial 19:
Spatial 20:
Spatial 21:
Spatial 22:
Spatial 23:
Spatial 24:
Date: 1864-06-17
Description: Letter "to the editors of the evening post" in the New England Loyal Publication Society, no. 198. The author, Edward Atkinson, argues that "the true policy of our government should be to allow free trade in cotton." He further argues that restricting the cotton trade has actually aided the rebels by reducing the supply, allowing successful blockade runners to realize higher prices; encouraging corruption of officers and agents; and depreciating our currency.
Subject-Topic: Commerce; United States--History--Civil War, 1861-1865; Transportation
Type-DCMI: Text
Type-AAT: circular letters
Identifier-DukeID: bdsma20824
Source: Broadsides and Ephemera Collection
Folder: MA2
Extent: 2 scans
Digital Collection: Broadsides and Ephemera Collection

Spatial 24:
Date: 1880; 1881; 1882; 1883; 1884; 1885; 1886; 1887; 1888; 1889; 1890; 1891; 1892; 1893; 1894; 1895; 1896; 1897; 1898; 1899; 1900; 1901; 1902; 1903; 1904; 1905; 1906; 1907; 1908; 1909; 1910; 1911; 1912; 1913; 1914; 1915; 1916; 1917; 1918; 1919; 1920; 1921; 1922; 1923; 1924; 1925; 1926; 1927; 1928; 1929; 1930
Description: Advertisement for a Republican rally in Randolph County at Ramseur High School. "All Republican candidates will be there." "All Republicans invited to be present."

Folder: NC11

Title: Courrier de la Louisiane, Nouvelle-Orlans, 12 Janvier, 1811
Country: United States
State: Louisiana
County: Saint John the Baptist Parish (La.)
City: Saint Charles Parish (La.)
Spatial 5: East Baton Rouge Parish (La.)
Spatial 6: Orleans Parish (La.)
Spatial 7: New Orleans (La.)
Spatial 8: Baton Rouge (La.)
Spatial 9:
Spatial 10:
Spatial 11:
Spatial 12:
Spatial 13:
Spatial 14:
Spatial 15:
Spatial 16:
Spatial 17:
Spatial 18:
Spatial 19:
Spatial 20:
Spatial 21:
Spatial 22:
Spatial 23:
Spatial 24:
Date: 1811-01-12
Description: Extracts from two letters, presented in parallel English and French, describing slave revolt known as the German Coast Uprising, January 1811. First letter, from General Wade Hampton to William Claiborne, governor of Orleans Territory, permitting detachments that came with him from New Orleans to return there; also ordering Light Artillery and Dragoons to descend from Baton Rouge. Second letter, from "Mr. Andry father" to Governor Claiborne, announcing capture of Charles Deslondes, "first chief of those bandittis." "Our detachments find many ranaways dead in the woods and three or four of the ringleaders are only missing but are perhaps expiring in some recess of the woods or probably taken by our men."
Subject-Topic: Slavery; African Americans--History
Type-DCMI: Text
Type-AAT: broadsides; ephemera
Identifier-DukeID: bdsla10557
Source: Broadsides and Ephemera Collection
Folder: LA1
Extent: 1 scan
Digital Collection: Broadsides and Ephemera Collection

Spatial 20:

Spatial 22:
Spatial 23:
Spatial 24:
Date: 1864-11-14
Description: Circular letter from George L. Stearns proposing creation of "association of men who take a deep interest in the settlement of the Freedman's future condition in the rebel States." Stearns wants to create directory of interested abolitionist parties with names and mailing addresses to facilitate communication among slavery opponents. Handwritten at top: Hon. Emory Washburn, Cambridge Mass." Handwritten at bottom: "Named [?] by Dr. Chs. Beck."
Subject-Topic: Slavery; Race relations
Type-DCMI: Text
Type-AAT: circular letters

Description: Portraits of 8 delegates at Methodist Episcopal Church convention held in Louisville on May 1, 1845: William Capers D.D., H.B. Bascom L.L.D., William Winans D.D., Bishop James O. Andrew D.D., Bishop Joshua Soule D.D., Lovick Pierce D.D., William A. Smith D.D., Robert Paine D.D. Other names handwritten on document. "Lith. of G. & W. Endicott, 22 John St., New York."
Subject-Topic: Religion
Type-DCMI: Text
Type-AAT: broadsides

Title: Democratic secrets leak
Country: United States
State: North Carolina
County: New Hanover County (N.C.)
City: Richmond County (N.C.)
Spatial 5: Wake County (N.C.)
Spatial 6:
Spatial 7:
Spatial 8:
Spatial 9:
Spatial 10:
Spatial 11:
Spatial 12:
Spatial 13:
Spatial 14:
Spatial 15:
Spatial 16:
Spatial 17:
Spatial 18:
Spatial 19:
Spatial 20:
Spatial 21:
Spatial 22:
Spatial 23:
Spatial 24:
Date: 1898-11-01
Description: Affidavit of Roscoe Mitchell ...("a red-hot Democrat"), signed by Geo. L. Tonnoffski, Deputy Clerk Superior Court Wake County, of an interview with Hon. Henry G. Williams, a former Democratic senator of Wilson County, about the scare tactics employed by the Democrats to work against the Fusionists to break "Negro domination" in Eastern counties, especially New Hanover and Richmond counties. When Mitchell asks if "the result be riot and bloodshed" if the Negro votes anyway, Williams replies "we would lay ourselves open to punishment" but "what we intend to do is bluff them away from the polls...". Mr. Pou, Geo. H. White, Atwater, and Chairman Simmons are also mentioned.
Subject-Topic: Political campaigns; Politics and government; Elections; African Americans--History; Race relations; Manners and customs;
Type-DCMI: Text
Type-AAT: broadsides;
Identifier-DukeID: bdsnc061815
Source: Broadsides and Ephemera Collection
Folder: NC6
Extent: 1 scan
Digital Collection: Broadsides and Ephemera Collection

Title: Democratic Success in 1892
Country: United States
State: Missouri
County: Saint Louis (Mo.)
City: Saint Louis (Mo.)
Spatial 5:
Spatial 6:
Spatial 7:
Spatial 8:
Spatial 9:
Spatial 10:
Spatial 11:
Spatial 12:
Spatial 13:
Spatial 14:
Spatial 15:
Spatial 16:
Spatial 17:
Spatial 18:
Spatial 19:
Spatial 20:
Spatial 21:
Spatial 22:
Spatial 23:
Spatial 24:
Date: 1892.0
Description: The first page of this document, written by the newspaper THE REPUBLIC, states that the newspaper is creating a Tariff Department in its daily and weekly editions to discuss the principles of the "so-called protective system and of the special provisions of the present law. It will show the falsity of the principles of Protection, and the iniquitous operation of the cunningly devised schedules of the McKinley Bill." This announcement comes a few earlier paragraphs stressing the need for tariff reform. The second page names Hon. William L. Wilson as the editor of the Tariff Department and informs readers about the subscription rate and states that the "Twice-a-Week REPUBLIC is already the most thoroughly and entirely national news journal in the whole country . . ."
Subject-Topic: Politics and government; Advertising
Type-DCMI: Text
Type-AAT: circular letters; advertisements

Date: 1880; 1881; 1882; 1883; 1884; 1885; 1886; 1887; 1888; 1889
Description: A request for data concerning soils, minerals, waters, vegetables, animals, and miscellaneous information to be found in each township so that a handbook detailing the resources available in South Carolina can be written and distributed. Signed by A.P. Butler, Commissioner Agriculture, S.C.
